div.p: In RPGs, most gameplay does not require rules. During play, players generally refer to rules only in the following instances:

ul.li: The game world is alien enough that common sense cannot be used to resolve a situation. This is the case for magic spell casting, for example.
Players and GMs share a common understanding that there is some nondeterministic influence—i.e. chance—in resolving a situation.
To resolve different understandings of a situation among players or GMs, provided the participants can agree on a probability value for certain outcomes.

div.p: Common rule systems create probabilities that are hard to gauge. In fact, only after playing a game for an extended period of time do patterns emerge. If the probabilities fail to meet expectations, enjoyment is affected.

The rules are written with these points in mind, which means: keep them comprehensible. This does not mean "generically simple," but rather that probabilities should not provide surprises when the subject matter changes.
The next section contains a few reasonable assumptions about rules and explains why our rules were chosen the way they are. If you are only interested in the mechanics, you can skip it.

Most rules aim to resolve skill application—whether it be fighting, hiding, finding, lifting, or something else. A character can have different skill levels, and tasks can also have different difficulty levels. We make the following assumptions:

ul.li: Skill proficiency and task difficulty can be expressed as numbers. We call half of the probability for a skill of 0 to succeed at a task of level 1 p. This "half" exists for technical reasons.

A skill level of k succeeds at a task of difficulty n+1 with the same probability as p times the probability that skill k succeeds at a task of difficulty n. That is, you succeed at reducing the difficulty by one as a first step and then tackle the remainder.
A skill level of k succeeds at a task of difficulty 0 with the same probability as skill level 0 at a task of difficulty -k.

div.p: The numbers m, n, k are regular (non-negative integers). In the setup above, we restrict ourselves to p=0.8. Note that the range of skill and task levels includes negative numbers. We treat a task level as a negative skill level—i.e. attempting a (-k)-skill at a 0-task is the same as using a 0-skill at a k-task.
This is, in fact, all we need. The following are conclusions. This section was written solely to show that we make very few, natural assumptions that already imply the most important rule.
